title: Traits for or_else, and_then, then ... etc. methods?

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Types like [`Option`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/option/enum.Option.html) and [`Result`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/result/enum.Result.html) have a kind of binary nature to them, and often I notice that I want to use the same kinds of logical operations on other types than these two (same with `map`, actually). An example would be [`std::poll::Poll`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/task/enum.Poll.html).

Option and Result already share this behaviour:
- and
- and_then
- or
- or_else
- map
- map_or
- map_or_else

Option also has:
- xor

Result also has:
- map_err

There are some other common methods, like `iter`, `unwrap` and some more. So this might be a more general question: Is it a good idea to put these methods into traits and implement them through those traits?

_**Why would you need that?**_
Although it will probably not provide a lot of code reuse, it does make these interfaces explicit and will make it more likely for crates to implement complete interfaces. This would discourage crates from implementing only `map` or only `and_then` or something like that. Also it might allow for generic programming against any type providing those methods.
For example `Poll` only implements `map` but not `and_then` or `or`, although these would make sense too.
